This
On
Week
List
Fiction
KEY OF VALOR, by Nora Roberts. (Jove, $7.99.) The third book in a trilogy about three women who go on life-changing journeys.
THE KING OF TORTS, by John Grisham. (Dell, $7.99.) A public defender in Washington happens upon a frightening conspiracy involving one of the largest pharmaceutical companies in the world.
DIGITAL FORTRESS, by Dan Brown. (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's, $14.95 and $7.99.) A cryptographer at the N.S.A. becomes enmeshed in murderous political intrigue after she breaks a mysterious code.
ANGELS & DEMONS, by Dan Brown. (Pocket Star, $7.99.) A Harvard scholar tries to save the Vatican from the machinations of an underground society.
COLD MOUNTAIN, by Charles Frazier. (Vintage, $14.95.) A wounded Confederate soldier journeys home to meet an old love and a new world.
A COLD HEART, by Jonathan Kellerman. (Ballantine, $7.99.) The psychologist-detective Alex Delaware investigates the murders of rising stars.
LUCKY'S LADY, by Tami Hoag. (Bantam, $7.99.) When her grandfather goes missing in Louisiana, a psychologist seeks the help of an enigmatic man.
KEY OF KNOWLEDGE, by Nora Roberts. (Jove, $7.99.) The second book in a trilogy about three women who go on life-changing journeys.
LATE BLOOMER, by Fern Michaels. (Pocket Star, $7.99.) Aided by her grandmother, a retired movie actress, a woman begins to recover memories of a childhood tragedy.
KEY OF LIGHT, by Nora Roberts. (Jove, $7.99.) A woman sets out on a dangerous quest that could alter her life forever.
THE SECRET LIFE OF BEES, by Sue Monk Kidd. (Penguin, $14.) In South Carolina in 1964, a teenage girl tries to discover the secret to her mother's past.
LIFE OF PI, by Yann Martel. (Harvest/Harcourt, $14.) An allegory on the high seas, in which a teenage boy and a 450-pound tiger are thrown together in a lifeboat as the only survivors of a shipwreck.
SLIGHTLY TEMPTED, by Mary Balogh. (Dell, $5.99.) In the early 1800's, Lady Morgan Bedwyn is courted by a notorious roué.

DECEPTION POINT, by Dan Brown. (Pocket Books, $7.99.) An intelligence analyst, sent to the Arctic on a special assignment by the White House, finds herself trying to escape a potentially deadly ambush.
PREY, by Michael Crichton. (Avon, $7.99.) In the Nevada desert, a team of scientists tries to undo an experiment involving nanoparticles -- molecule-sized robots -- that has gone disastrously wrong.
Weeks
This
On
Week
List
Nonfiction
TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Broadway, $11.95.) The author tells of his visits to his old college mentor, who was near death's door.
SEABISCUIT, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Ballantine, $15.95 and $7.99.) The story of the horse whose career culminated in a 1938 match race with War Admiral.
BRINGING DOWN THE HOUSE, by Ben Mezrich. (Free Press, $14.) How six M.I.T. students won more than $3 million at Las Vegas casinos.
THE LORD OF THE RINGS: Weapons and Warfare, by Chris Smith. (Houghton Mifflin, $18.95.) An illustrated guide to battles, armies and armor.
PORTRAIT OF A KILLER, by Patricia Cornwell. (Berkley, $7.99.) The novelist presents evidence that the artist Walter Sickert was Jack the Ripper.
UNDER THE TUSCAN SUN, by Frances Mayes. (Broadway, $15.) A celebration of life in the Italian countryside.
WHAT SHOULD I DO WITH MY LIFE? by Po Bronson. (Random House, $14.95.) The stories of 55 people who found their calling after years of struggle. (+)
RUNNING WITH SCISSORS, by Augusten Burroughs. (Picador, $14.) A memoir of a psychiatrist who went crazy while the author was in his care.

HOLY BLOOD, HOLY GRAIL, by Michael Baigent, Richard Leigh and Henry Lincoln. (Dell, $7.99.) Some extraordinary conclusions about the lineage of Christ, based upon documents uncovered by BBC producers.
WITHOUT PITY, by Ann Rule. (Pocket Books, $7.99.) A collection of three new true-crime stories and nine earlier ones that the author has updated.
FAST FOOD NATION, by Eric Schlosser. (Peren-nial/HarperCollins, $13.95.) A survey of ''the dark side of the all-American meal.''
MICHELANGELO & THE POPE'S CEILING, by Ross King. (Penguin, $15.) The painting of the Sistine Chapel's ceiling and the circumstances surrounding it.
*READING LOLITA IN TEHRAN, by Azar Nafisi. (Random House, $13.95.) A memoir of a teacher's life in Iran, centered on a reading group she organized for seven of her former students (all women).
THE SEA HUNTERS II, by Clive Cussler and Craig Dirgo. (Berkley, $7.99.) More accounts of the searches made for famous shipwrecks.
NICKEL AND DIMED, by Barbara Ehrenreich. (Metropolitan/Owl/Holt, $13.) What it was like to become a member of the working poor.
*A CHILD CALLED ''IT,'' by Dave Pelzer. (Health Communications, $9.95.) The autobiography of a man who survived his mother's abuse. (+)

Week
List
Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous: Hardcover
THE SOUTH BEACH DIET, by Arthur Agatston. (Rodale, $24.95.) A weight-loss plan designed by a Miami cardiologist. (+)
THE PURPOSE-DRIVEN LIFE, by Rick Warren. (Zondervan, $19.99.) Finding the meaning of life through God. (+)
THE ULTIMATE WEIGHT SOLUTION, by Phil McGraw. (Free Press, $26.) Dr. Phil identifies ''seven keys'' to losing weight.
THE WORLD ACCORDING TO MISTER ROGERS, by Fred Rogers. (Hyperion, $16.95.) Inspirational words from the TV personality, who died last year.
THE PRESENT, by Spencer Johnson. (Doubleday, $19.95.) An inspirational parable about the search for happiness, by the author of ''Who Moved My Cheese?'' (+)

On
Week
List
Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous: Paperback
DR. ATKINS' NEW DIET REVOLUTION, by Robert C. Atkins. (Quill, $13.95; Avon, $7.99.) Ways to lose weight and achieve a healthy body. (+)
THE ATKINS ESSENTIALS, by Atkins Health and Medical Information Services. (Avon, $7.50.) A two-week program for starting the diet. (+)
THE WORLD ALMANAC AND BOOK OF FACTS 2004. (World Almanac, $11.95.) The latest edition of a reference work issued annually since 1868.
RICH DAD, POOR DAD, by Robert T. Kiyosaki with Sharon L. Lechter. (Warner, $15.95.) Teaching one's children how to get rich and stay rich.
WHAT TO EXPECT WHEN YOU'RE EXPECTING, by Heidi Murkoff, Arlene Eisenberg and Sandee Hathaway. (Workman, $13.95.) For parents-to-be. (+)

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Jan. 3, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 60,000 other retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets), statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: nytimes.com/books.
